header: The Holy Place of the Temple

verse: The man brought me to the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall] and measured its ·side walls [or jambs], which were each ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] thick.

The entrance was ·seventeen and one-half feet [ten cubits] wide. The walls alongside the entrance were each ·about nine feet wide [five cubits]. The man measured the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall], which was ·seventy feet [forty cubits] long and ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] wide.

Then the man went ·inside [into the inner sanctuary] and measured the ·side walls [or jambs] of the next doorway. Each was ·three and one-half feet [two cubits] thick. The doorway was ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] wide, and the walls next to it were each more than ·twelve [seven cubits] feet thick.

Then the man measured the room ·at the end of [or adjacent to] the ·Holy Place [outer sanctuary; main hall]. It was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] long and ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] long wide. The man said to me, “This is the Most Holy Place.”
Then the man measured the wall of the ·Temple [house], which was ·ten and one-half feet [six cubits] thick. There were side rooms ·seven feet [four cubits] wide all around the Temple.

The side rooms were on three different stories, each above the other, with thirty rooms on each story. All around the Temple walls there were ledges for the side rooms. The upper rooms rested on the ledges but were not attached to the Temple walls.

The side rooms around the Temple were wider on each higher story, so rooms were wider on the top story. ·A stairway went [or So one went] up from the lowest story to the highest through the middle story.
I also saw that the Temple had a raised ·base [platform] all around. Its edge was the foundation for the side rooms, and it was ·ten and one-half feet thick [a full rod/stick of six cubits].
The outer wall of the side rooms was ·about nine feet [five cubits] thick. There was an open area between the side rooms of the Temple
and some other rooms. It was ·thirty-five feet [twenty cubits] wide and went all around the Temple.

The side rooms had doors which led to the open area around the outside of the Temple. One door faced north, and the other faced south. The open area was ·about nine feet [five cubits] wide all around.

The building facing the ·private area [temple courtyard] at the west side was ·one hundred twenty-two and one-half feet [seventy cubits] wide. The wall around the building was ·about nine feet [five cubits] thick and ·one hundred fifty-seven and one-half feet [ninety cubits] long.

Then the man measured the Temple. It was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long. The ·private area [temple courtyard], including the building and its walls, was in all ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] long.
Also the front of the Temple and the ·private area [courtyard] on its east side were ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] wide.

The man measured the length of the building facing the ·private area [courtyard] ·on the west side [or at the rear], and it was ·one hundred seventy-five feet [one hundred cubits] ·from one wall to the other [or with its galleries on each side].
had wood panels on the walls. By the ·doorway [thresholds], the Temple had wood panels on the walls. The wood covered all the walls from the floor up to the windows,
up to the part of the wall above the entrance.
had carvings of ·creatures with wings [cherubim] and palm trees. A palm tree was between each ·carved creature [cherub], and every ·creature [cherub] had two faces.
One was a human face looking toward the palm tree on one side. The other was a lion’s face looking toward the palm tree on the other side. They were carved all around the Temple walls.
From the floor to above the entrance, palm trees and ·creatures with wings [cherubim] were carved. The walls of the Holy Place
had square doorposts. In front of the ·Most Holy Place [sanctuary] was something that looked like

an altar of wood. It was more than ·five feet [three cubits] high and ·three feet [two cubits] wide. Its corners, base, and sides were wood. The man said to me, “This is the table that is ·in the presence of [before] the Lord.”
Both the ·Holy Place [main hall; outer sanctuary] and the ·Most Holy Place [inner sanctuary] had double doors.
Each of the doors had two ·pieces [leaves] that would swing open. Two for one and two for the other.

Carved on the doors of the ·Holy Place [main hall; outer sanctuary] were palm trees and ·creatures with wings [cherubim], like those carved on the walls. And there was a wood ·roof [canopy] over the front Temple ·porch [portico].
There were narrow windows and palm trees on both side walls of the ·porch [portico]. The side rooms of the Temple were also covered by a ·roof [canopy] over the stairway.
